'''Johnny "Big Moose" Walker''' (June 27, 1927{{spaced ndash}} November 27, 1999) was an American [[Chicago blues|Chicago]] and [[electric blues]] pianist and organist.  He worked with many blues musicians including [[Ike Turner]], [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]], [[Lowell Fulson]], [[Choker Campbell]], [[Elmore James]], [[Earl Hooker]], [[Muddy Waters]], [[Otis Spann]], [[Sunnyland Slim]], [[Jimmy Dawkins]] and [[Son Seals]].<ref name="AMG"/>

In addition to his virtuoso piano playing, Walker was proficient on the [[electric organ]] and [[bass guitar]], playing the latter instrument when backing Muddy Waters. As well as playing accompaniment to other musicians in both concert and recording arenas, Walker recorded a small number of  solo albums.<ref name="AMG"/>

==Life and career==
'''John Mayon Walker''' was born in the [[Unincorporated area|unincorporated community]] of [[Stoneville, Mississippi]], United States, partly of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] ancestry.<ref name="AMG"/> He acquired his best known [[stage name]] in his childhood in [[Greenville, Mississippi]], derived from his long flowing hairstyle.<ref name="Alligator"/> Walker learned to play a number of [[musical instrument|instruments]] including [[church organ]], [[guitar]], [[vibraphone]] and [[tuba]].<ref name="AMG"/>

It was as a pianist that he started his musical career in 1947, and toured in various blues bands variously backing notable artists such as [[Ike Turner]], [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]], [[Elmore James]], [[Lowell Fulson]] and [[Choker Campbell]]. Walker served in the [[United States Army]] from 1952 to 1955, taking part in the [[Korean War]].<ref name="AMG"/> In 1955, billed as Moose John, Ultra Records released the [[Single (music)|single]], "Talkin' 'Bout Me".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Moose-John-Talkin-Bout-Me-Wrong-Doin-Woman/release/735344 |title=Moose John - Talkin' 'Bout Me / Wrong Doin' Woman (Vinyl) at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref> Although his own recordings under a selection of names were unsuccessful, Walker started working more consistently in the mid 1950s, particularly backing both [[Earl Hooker]] and Elmore James.<ref name="AMG"/> Relocating to Chicago in the late 1950s, over the next decade Walker then accompanied [[Sunnyland Slim]], [[Otis Rush]], [[Muddy Waters]] (on bass guitar), [[Ricky Allen]], [[Little Johnny Jones (pianist)|Little Johnny Jones]], and [[Howlin' Wolf]].<ref name="Guardian"/> In 1960, Walker accompanied [[Junior Wells]] on his best known recording, "[[Messin' with the Kid]]".<ref>
{{Cite book
  | last = Danchin
  | first = Sebastian
  | authorlink = 
  | coauthors = 
  | title = Earl Hooker: Blues Master
  | publisher = [[University Press of Mississippi]]
  | year = 2001
  | location = 
  | pages = 132–33
  | url = 
  | doi = 
  | id = 
  | isbn = 1-57806-306-X}}
</ref> The following year Walker appeared on Elmore James' recordings of "[[Look on Yonder Wall]]" and "[[Shake Your Moneymaker (song)|Shake Your Moneymaker]]". In 1962, Walker played on Muddy Waters recording of "[[You Shook Me]]". During the 1960s, a couple of obscure Chicago based record labels, Age and The Blues, released Walker's solo singles.<ref name="Alligator"/>

By 1969, Walker had rejoined Earl Hooker and played on the latter's album, ''Don't Have to Worry'' (ABC Bluesway).<ref name="Alligator"/> Following Hooker's death the following year, Walker played backing for [[Jimmy Dawkins]], [[Mighty Joe Young (musician)|Mighty Joe Young]] and [[Louis Myers]].<ref name="Alligator"/> His own debut album was issued in 1970, when ABC released ''Ramblin Woman''. Further piano accompaniment from Walker was supplied on Andrew Odom's ''Farther on the Road'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/farther-on-the-road-mw0000860008/credits |title=Farther on the Road - Andrew Odom : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref> and ''If You Miss 'Im...I Got 'Im'', by [[John Lee Hooker]] featuring Earl Hooker.<ref name="Guardian"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/if-you-miss-imi-got-im-mw0000044575/credits |title=If You Miss 'Im...I Got 'Im - John Lee Hooker : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref>

[[Alligator Records]] utilised Walker's playing on their ''Living Chicago Blues'' series of recordings.<ref name="Alligator"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/living-chicago-blues-vol-1-mw0000675605/credits |title=Living Chicago Blues, Vol. 1 - Various Artists : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref> He toured Europe in 1979 with the Chicago Blues Festival,<ref name="Guardian"/> saw his second album, ''Blue Love'', released in 1984<ref name="allmusic1">{{cite web|last=Thomas |first=Stephen |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/blue-love-mw0000074114 |title=Blue Love - Johnny "Big Moose" Walker : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=1996-09-03 |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref> and later toured both in New Zealand and Canada.<ref name="Guardian"/>  He recorded with [[Son Seals]],<ref name="AMG"/> and appeared at the Burnley Blues Festival in England in 1991.<ref name="Guardian"/> Walker had suffered a stroke prior to this engagement, and he had a series of others which left him unable to perform.<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news|author=Tony Russell |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/2000/feb/03/guardianobituaries2 |title=Big Moose Walker |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= 2000-02-03|accessdate=2013-03-11 |location=London}}</ref> The 1996 reissue of ''Blue Love'' by [[Evidence Music]] had five bonus tracks.<ref name="allmusic1"/> 

Walker lived for a while in a nursing home in Chicago before his death, at the age of 72, in November 1999.<ref name="Alligator">{{cite web|url=http://www.alligator.com/artists/Johnny-Big-Moose-Walker/ |title=Alligator Records |publisher=Alligator.com |date=1927-06-27 |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref>
